poem:
"Desert Bloom, Area of Dispute"

Red, blue, under the Arizona sun,
Agendas rise and set,
The 1864 law, in silent repose,
Roused by a heartbeat's debate.

A woman's right, a child's fate,
Both precariously perch,
On-house-on-Senate scroll,
The battleground bell does toll.

The supreme hand tilts the scale,
Under the desert's aloof gaze,
Life and choice, in heated play,
Echo through the centuries' maze.

The Arizona supreme court earlier this month concluded the state can enforce a long-dormant law that permits abortions only to save the pregnant patient’s life.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
